title: Unexpected type inference around unsized coercion
body: I tried this code: ```rust use std::any::Any; use std::rc::Rc; fn main() { let x = Rc::new(42i32); f(Rc::clone(&x)); } fn f(_: Rc) {} ``` I expected to see this happen: Line 6 to infer ```rust f(Rc::::clone(&x)); ``` and compile successfully. Instead, this happened: ``` error[[E0308]](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/error-index.html#E0308): mismatched types --> src/main.rs:6:17 | 6 | f(Rc::clone(&x)); | --------- ^^ expected trait object `dyn Any`, found `i32` | | | arguments to this function are incorrect | = note: expected reference `&Rc` found reference `&Rc` note: associated function defined here ``` Changing line 6 to ```rust f(Rc::::clone(&x)); ``` works as expected, leading me to believe that the current behavior is inferring ```rust f(Rc::::clone(&x)); ``` (which gives the same error). Also of note is that moving `x` rather that borrowing works as expected, e.g. ```rust fn id(x: Rc) -> Rc { x } f(id(x)); ``` Presumably, the difference is that ```rust f(id::(x)); ``` works fine by coercing `x` before the call to `id`, whereas `&Rc` can't be coerced to `&Rc`, so the coercion must happen after the call to `Rc::clone`, which doesn't play well with type inference. ### Meta `rustc --version --verbose`: ``` rustc 1.65.0 (897e37553 2022-11-02) binary: rustc commit-hash: 897e37553bba8b42751c67658967889d11ecd120 commit-date: 2022-11-02 host: x86_64-pc-windows-msvc release: 1.65.0 LLVM version: 15.0.0 ```
